revisions.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/Matza Pizza|Matza Pizza]] ([[User talk:Matza Pizza|talk]]): No
This tidbit isn't really relevant to an already-long lead; I moved the note down to its reference in the text. The mention of his citizenship in Prussia is also not corroborated by the text

Restored revision 1334558045 by [[Special:Contributions/Citation bot|Citation bot]] ([[User talk:Citation bot|talk]]): Let's bring this to the talk page it's not something that's really covered in the article to be jammed into the lead like this.

There has been a growing consensus among the philosophical and physics communities that Albert Einstein was not only a philosopher, but arguably the most prominent philosopher of physics and science of the twentieth century. Some even regard him as the first philosopher of physics. His work on special and general relativity, as Einstein himself stated, would not have been possible without his extensive reading of David Hume.
